values.description:
1. Allow `ignLogInit` to use an absolute path.
2. Added a `timeToIso` that converts a given time to an ISO string.
3. Some console timestamps were using `IGN_SYSTEM_TIME_NS()` and others `ignition::common::systemTimeISO()`. Switched all to use `ignition::common::systemTimeISO()`.
values.title: Update logging to support specification of an absolute path, and fixed/updated a few related functions

summary.raw:
1. Allow `ignLogInit` to use an absolute path.
2. Added a `timeToIso` that converts a given time to an ISO string.
3. Some console timestamps were using `IGN_SYSTEM_TIME_NS()` and others `ignition::common::systemTimeISO()`. Switched all to use `ignition::common::systemTimeISO()`.
summary.html:
1. Allow ignLogInit to use an absolute path.
  2. Added a timeToIso that converts a given time to an ISO string.
  3. Some console timestamps were using IGN_SYSTEM_TIME_NS() and others ignition::common::systemTimeISO(). Switched all to use ignition::common::systemTimeISO().

values.description:
The `SystemPaths` class supports a few ways of specifying different paths, such as adding them through `SystemPaths::AddFilePaths` or by specifying an environment variable with `SetFilePathEnv`. Those paths are then considered when using `SystemPaths::FindFile` to locate a file. But they were not being used with the `SystemPaths::FindFileURI` call.

This PR uses the custom paths when finding a URI, by treating them as relative paths and ignoring the URI's scheme. For example, if the user sets `IGN_FILE_PATH=/tmp/files`, then tries to get a URI `custom://mesh.dae`, the user is able to load file `/tmp/files/mesh.dae`.

I'm not entirely convinced yet that ignoring the scheme like that is a good idea, but I can't think of how it could cause an issue. The worst thing that can happen is that the user finds an existing file that they didn't mean to find?
values.title: [Proposal] Custom paths for file URIs

summary.raw:
The `SystemPaths` class supports a few ways of specifying different paths, such as adding them through `SystemPaths::AddFilePaths` or by specifying an environment variable with `SetFilePathEnv`. Those paths are then considered when using `SystemPaths::FindFile` to locate a file. But they were not being used with the `SystemPaths::FindFileURI` call.

This PR uses the custom paths when finding a URI, by treating them as relative paths and ignoring the URI's scheme. For example, if the user sets `IGN_FILE_PATH=/tmp/files`, then tries to get a URI `custom://mesh.dae`, the user is able to load file `/tmp/files/mesh.dae`.

I'm not entirely convinced yet that ignoring the scheme like that is a good idea, but I can't think of how it could cause an issue. The worst thing that can happen is that the user finds an existing file that they didn't mean to find?
summary.html:
The SystemPaths class supports a few ways of specifying different paths, such as adding them through SystemPaths::AddFilePaths or by specifying an environment variable with SetFilePathEnv. Those paths are then considered when using SystemPaths::FindFile to locate a file. But they were not being used with the SystemPaths::FindFileURI call.

This PR uses the custom paths when finding a URI, by treating them as relative paths and ignoring the URI's scheme. For example, if the user sets IGN_FILE_PATH=/tmp/files, then tries to get a URI custom://mesh.dae, the user is able to load file /tmp/files/mesh.dae.

I'm not entirely convinced yet that ignoring the scheme like that is a good idea, but I can't think of how it could cause an issue. The worst thing that can happen is that the user finds an existing file that they didn't mean to find?

values.description: The `BAYER_BGGR8` pixel format was added to ign-common3 in pull request #192. It was intended to replace the incorrect `BAYER_RGGR8`, but the incorrect type was retained to preserve API, and the correct type was appended to the end of the enum. The `ConvertPixelFormat` function was not updated, however, and doesn't work for the added type. I've added a failing test in 32e157b, and fixed it in 345469a.
values.title: Fix `Image::ConvertPixelFormat` for BAYER_BGGR8

summary.raw: The `BAYER_BGGR8` pixel format was added to ign-common3 in pull request #192. It was intended to replace the incorrect `BAYER_RGGR8`, but the incorrect type was retained to preserve API, and the correct type was appended to the end of the enum. The `ConvertPixelFormat` function was not updated, however, and doesn't work for the added type. I've added a failing test in 32e157b, and fixed it in 345469a.
summary.html: The BAYER_BGGR8 pixel format was added to ign-common3 in pull request #192. It was intended to replace the incorrect BAYER_RGGR8, but the incorrect type was retained to preserve API, and the correct type was appended to the end of the enum. The ConvertPixelFormat function was not updated, however, and doesn't work for the added type. I've added a failing test in 32e157b, and fixed it in 345469a.

values.description:
* port collada loader stride fix

* changelog

* Close branch collada_stride

* Change default profiling to aggregate

    This will cause multiple samples of the same type to be reported as an
    aggregate value for timing. It will also report the number of times
    a profiling point was called.

* Codecheck.

* Make Timeline larger for looking at more threads

* Close branch rmt_timeline

* dependencies for logging resources

* tests

* codecheck

* coverage

* Close branch profiler_aggregate

* try to make test more portable

* recursive copy dir test

* replace slashes with separators

* create directories recursively before copy

* revert

* add checks and test

* coverage

* Update logging to support specification of an absolute path, and fixed/updated a few related functions

* Docs and changelog

* Use systemTimeIso

* Close branch console_logging_tweaks

* 3.2.0

* Added tag ignition-common3_3.2.0 for changeset 7a478aa5c2ba

* add warning flag

* add bvh animation support for skeleton

* reformat codes

* clear before when adding a new animation

* add trajectory info class in animation

* fix a typo

* add TrajectoryInfo class

* correct errors in comments

* fix a typo

* use chrono duration instead of double

* add unit tests for TrajectoryInfo

* More chrono on TrajectoryInfo

* remove SetDuration declaration

* Address feedback on PR #197, fix BVH loader crash

* use temp dir on test

* make tests verbose

* port pr from gazebo9-collada-fix

    fix wrong node weights caused by buffer overflow bug

* blindly trying something out on windows

* revert windows change, add a test

* Bump to 3.3.0

* attempt at skipping . and ..

* fix infinite loop

* initialize char array

* debugging on jenkins like a pro

* fix next file

* code check

* Close branch log_resources

* skip GTSMeshUtils test on Windows due to issue #50

* Close branch disable_gts_test_windows

* changelog for 200

* Close branch bump_3.3.0

* Added tag ignition-common3_3.3.0 for changeset 818bcd7029c8

* Return the given library name if it exists

* Close branch find_lib_short_circuit

* changeset: 1659:aabcd0e67497
    branch: collada-fix-port
    parent: 1582:db2da2c26347
    user: Koon Peng <koonpeng@openrobotics.org>

* Port skeleton fixes from Gazebo

* style

* Close branch porting_skeleton_fixes

* Add test for Image::ConvertPixelFormat function

* fix test for BAYER_BGGR8, since it was added after PIXEL_FORMAT_COUNT to preserve API

* changelog

* more changelog

* Changelog.md edited online with Bitbucket

* pr number. Changelog.md edited online with Bitbucket

* Close branch convert_bayer_bggr8

values.description:
We were not properly handling URI authorities. See 
 the following [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier#Generic_syntax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier#Generic_syntax).

The most important change is deprecation of `file://`. The proper syntax is `file:`.
values.title: Uri authority

summary.raw:
We were not properly handling URI authorities. See 
 the following [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier#Generic_syntax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier#Generic_syntax).

The most important change is deprecation of `file://`. The proper syntax is `file:`.
summary.html:
We were not properly handling URI authorities. See the following https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier#Generic_syntax.

The most important change is deprecation of file://. The proper syntax is file:.

summary.html: This adds a helper function to Mesh and SubMesh that returns the volume of a mesh.

values.description:
Fixes blender generated collada files with actors with multiple skeletons.

Actors generated in blender have a root node called for the Armature in the library\_animation, however a root node called dummy-root is generated when parsing the library\_controller. Since they have different names they are not merged even though the Armature contains all the nodes parsed in the library\_controller.

This behavior resulted in duplicated bones being added to the mesh, which resulted in OGRE crashing and failing to spawn the models.

Note that there is a possible memory leak \(also present before this commit\) in MergeSkeleton when assigning a new value to the Skeleton root, since a new tree is assigned but the old one \(dynamically allocated with new\) is not deleted.

I have a few ideas how to fix it but for now left as a TODO for documentation.
values.title: Collada multiple skeletons

summary.raw:
Fixes blender generated collada files with actors with multiple skeletons.

Actors generated in blender have a root node called for the Armature in the library\_animation, however a root node called dummy-root is generated when parsing the library\_controller. Since they have different names they are not merged even though the Armature contains all the nodes parsed in the library\_controller.

This behavior resulted in duplicated bones being added to the mesh, which resulted in OGRE crashing and failing to spawn the models.

Note that there is a possible memory leak \(also present before this commit\) in MergeSkeleton when assigning a new value to the Skeleton root, since a new tree is assigned but the old one \(dynamically allocated with new\) is not deleted.

I have a few ideas how to fix it but for now left as a TODO for documentation.
summary.html:
Fixes blender generated collada files with actors with multiple skeletons.

Actors generated in blender have a root node called for the Armature in the library_animation, however a root node called dummy-root is generated when parsing the library_controller. Since they have different names they are not merged even though the Armature contains all the nodes parsed in the library_controller.

This behavior resulted in duplicated bones being added to the mesh, which resulted in OGRE crashing and failing to spawn the models.

Note that there is a possible memory leak (also present before this commit) in MergeSkeleton when assigning a new value to the Skeleton root, since a new tree is assigned but the old one (dynamically allocated with new) is not deleted.

I have a few ideas how to fix it but for now left as a TODO for documentation.

values.description:
This pull request addresses the situation where a MTL file has a map_Kd and no Kd. In this situation the default diffuse value of 0,0,0 is used. The problem is that this results in a black material.

Other programs, such as blender, use a higher default diffuse value. I believe blender uses 0.6, which I also use here.

Matching upstream PR: https://github.com/syoyo/tinyobjloader/pull/249
values.title: Set a decent diffuse value when map_Kd is present and Kd is not specified

summary.raw:
This pull request addresses the situation where a MTL file has a map_Kd and no Kd. In this situation the default diffuse value of 0,0,0 is used. The problem is that this results in a black material.

Other programs, such as blender, use a higher default diffuse value. I believe blender uses 0.6, which I also use here.

Matching upstream PR: https://github.com/syoyo/tinyobjloader/pull/249
summary.html:
This pull request addresses the situation where a MTL file has a map_Kd and no Kd. In this situation the default diffuse value of 0,0,0 is used. The problem is that this results in a black material.

Other programs, such as blender, use a higher default diffuse value. I believe blender uses 0.6, which I also use here.

Matching upstream PR: https://github.com/syoyo/tinyobjloader/pull/249

values.description:
While trying to load an animated 2-bone cylinder from @{5b6a0f313df2033d0d9a151a}, I ran into several places in our COLLADA loading where assumptions are made about the file structure, and if they're not met, the entire application crashes.

Even if the user is trying to load an invalid COLLADA file, I don't think we should crash. So I added several `nullptr` checks with error messages so that the problem can be traced back.

Now loading Cole's animation (below under `test/data`) doesn't crash, but it looks deformed. ~~I'll look into that later, as well as write a proper test to load the file.~~ I suggest we get this PR in and revisit the deformation later.
values.title: Handle unexpected COLLADA more gracefully

summary.raw:
While trying to load an animated 2-bone cylinder from @{5b6a0f313df2033d0d9a151a}, I ran into several places in our COLLADA loading where assumptions are made about the file structure, and if they're not met, the entire application crashes.

Even if the user is trying to load an invalid COLLADA file, I don't think we should crash. So I added several `nullptr` checks with error messages so that the problem can be traced back.

Now loading Cole's animation (below under `test/data`) doesn't crash, but it looks deformed. ~~I'll look into that later, as well as write a proper test to load the file.~~ I suggest we get this PR in and revisit the deformation later.
summary.html:
While trying to load an animated 2-bone cylinder from @Cole Biesemeyer, I ran into several places in our COLLADA loading where assumptions are made about the file structure, and if they're not met, the entire application crashes.

Even if the user is trying to load an invalid COLLADA file, I don't think we should crash. So I added several nullptr checks with error messages so that the problem can be traced back.

Now loading Cole's animation (below under test/data) doesn't crash, but it looks deformed. I'll look into that later, as well as write a proper test to load the file. I suggest we get this PR in and revisit the deformation later.

values.description:
The `MeshManager` uses the global `findFile` interface to find meshes.

This change exposes the global `SystemPaths`'s `AddFindFileURICallback` function so `ign-gazebo` can add a `ign-fuel-tools` callback to find meshes.
values.title: Support custom callbacks to find files on global interface

summary.raw:
The `MeshManager` uses the global `findFile` interface to find meshes.

This change exposes the global `SystemPaths`'s `AddFindFileURICallback` function so `ign-gazebo` can add a `ign-fuel-tools` callback to find meshes.
summary.html:
The MeshManager uses the global findFile interface to find meshes.

This change exposes the global SystemPaths's AddFindFileURICallback function so ign-gazebo can add a ign-fuel-tools callback to find meshes.

values.description:
Extended Materials to capture PBR params using a new Pbr class. 

The class ended up very similar to the [Pbr](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/default/include/sdf/Pbr.hh) class in sdformat with one small difference. The sdformat PBR class is designed to store multiple PBR workflows \(i.e. users can specify both `<metal>` and `<specular>` workflows and the two workflows will be stored in  `sdf::Pbr` \) but the PBR class in ign-common is designed to represent only one PBR material with a single workflow.  Despite the difference, there’s still quite a bit of duplicate code.
values.title: Add PBR material class

summary.raw:
Extended Materials to capture PBR params using a new Pbr class. 

The class ended up very similar to the [Pbr](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/default/include/sdf/Pbr.hh) class in sdformat with one small difference. The sdformat PBR class is designed to store multiple PBR workflows \(i.e. users can specify both `<metal>` and `<specular>` workflows and the two workflows will be stored in  `sdf::Pbr` \) but the PBR class in ign-common is designed to represent only one PBR material with a single workflow.  Despite the difference, there’s still quite a bit of duplicate code.
summary.html:
Extended Materials to capture PBR params using a new Pbr class.

The class ended up very similar to the Pbr class in sdformat with one small difference. The sdformat PBR class is designed to store multiple PBR workflows (i.e. users can specify both <metal> and <specular> workflows and the two workflows will be stored in sdf::Pbr ) but the PBR class in ign-common is designed to represent only one PBR material with a single workflow. Despite the difference, there’s still quite a bit of duplicate code.

values.description:
Add interpolate\_x boolean property to match the sdf tag in animation objects.

Notes that I’d like some feedback on:

* The Animation class doesn’t seem to follow PIMPL, for this reason I believe this PR is ABI breaking, is this intended? I can pimplize it either in this PR or in a followup one to make modifying it easier in the future.
* I didn’t add the interpolate\_x constructor parameter to NumericAnimation since I can’t quite figure out where it is used and if it is relevant.

Needed for ign-gazebo PR [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/536](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/536)
values.title: Added interpolate_x feature to animations

summary.html:
Add interpolate_x boolean property to match the sdf tag in animation objects.

Notes that I’d like some feedback on:

  • The Animation class doesn’t seem to follow PIMPL, for this reason I believe this PR is ABI breaking, is this intended? I can pimplize it either in this PR or in a followup one to make modifying it easier in the future.
  • I didn’t add the interpolate_x constructor parameter to NumericAnimation since I can’t quite figure out where it is used and if it is relevant.

Needed for ign-gazebo PR #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/536

values.reason: Closed in favor of #232 targeting ign-common3. PR removing the static map will follow.

values.description:
Loading an obj mesh with a material that doesn’t exist \(i.e. a blank material and no .mtl file\) causes a segmentation fault in the OBJLoader.

This is a port of the [fix in gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2888) by @{557058:095b1e12-74ed-4e20-b44f-2f0745b616e0} , including the test.  
I also changed the iteration variable to be a constant reference to avoid unnecessary copies.

Note, the unit test without the change doesn’t fail, it segfaults in the Load function.
values.title: Port obj invalid mtl fix from gazebo

summary.raw:
Loading an obj mesh with a material that doesn’t exist \(i.e. a blank material and no .mtl file\) causes a segmentation fault in the OBJLoader.

This is a port of the [fix in gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2888) by @{557058:095b1e12-74ed-4e20-b44f-2f0745b616e0} , including the test.  
I also changed the iteration variable to be a constant reference to avoid unnecessary copies.

Note, the unit test without the change doesn’t fail, it segfaults in the Load function.
summary.html:
Loading an obj mesh with a material that doesn’t exist (i.e. a blank material and no .mtl file) causes a segmentation fault in the OBJLoader.

This is a port of the fix in gazebo by @Nate Koenig , including the test.
I also changed the iteration variable to be a constant reference to avoid unnecessary copies.

Note, the unit test without the change doesn’t fail, it segfaults in the Load function.

values.description:
To be used with [ign-rendering PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/238)

This PR sets default PBR properties \(currently only metalness value\) for mesh loaders that do not natively support PBR.

The main motivation behind this PR is to reduce the effort needed when porting models from gazebo-classic to ignition. There is a noticeable shading difference between ogre 1.x and ogre 2.x. One factor is ogre 2.x’s default metalness value that causes objects to appear darker when compared to ogre 1.x. With these changes and the [ign-rendering PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/238), the models should appear brighter.

The changes should not affect users who are already using PBR maps \(metalness, normal, and roughness maps\) for their models because the default values are overriden. e.g. subt should not be affected.

Other thing I’ve considered:

* It is possible for users to override the metalness value through SDF but that involves modifying the model.sdf files of all assets. It is also not straight forward when there are multiple submeshes in a mesh with different textures.
* Override metalness value in the ign-gazebo level. This is not desirable as we integrate new mesh formats with PBR support in the future, e.g. glTF2. The metalness value specified in the mesh would be overriden.

**Update:**

Ended up changing default metalness value in common::Pbr class.
values.title: Set default PBR metalness value

summary.raw:
To be used with [ign-rendering PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/238)

This PR sets default PBR properties \(currently only metalness value\) for mesh loaders that do not natively support PBR.

The main motivation behind this PR is to reduce the effort needed when porting models from gazebo-classic to ignition. There is a noticeable shading difference between ogre 1.x and ogre 2.x. One factor is ogre 2.x’s default metalness value that causes objects to appear darker when compared to ogre 1.x. With these changes and the [ign-rendering PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/238), the models should appear brighter.

The changes should not affect users who are already using PBR maps \(metalness, normal, and roughness maps\) for their models because the default values are overriden. e.g. subt should not be affected.

Other thing I’ve considered:

* It is possible for users to override the metalness value through SDF but that involves modifying the model.sdf files of all assets. It is also not straight forward when there are multiple submeshes in a mesh with different textures.
* Override metalness value in the ign-gazebo level. This is not desirable as we integrate new mesh formats with PBR support in the future, e.g. glTF2. The metalness value specified in the mesh would be overriden.

**Update:**

Ended up changing default metalness value in common::Pbr class.
summary.html:
To be used with ign-rendering PR

This PR sets default PBR properties (currently only metalness value) for mesh loaders that do not natively support PBR.

The main motivation behind this PR is to reduce the effort needed when porting models from gazebo-classic to ignition. There is a noticeable shading difference between ogre 1.x and ogre 2.x. One factor is ogre 2.x’s default metalness value that causes objects to appear darker when compared to ogre 1.x. With these changes and the ign-rendering PR, the models should appear brighter.

The changes should not affect users who are already using PBR maps (metalness, normal, and roughness maps) for their models because the default values are overriden. e.g. subt should not be affected.

Other thing I’ve considered:

  • It is possible for users to override the metalness value through SDF but that involves modifying the model.sdf files of all assets. It is also not straight forward when there are multiple submeshes in a mesh with different textures.
  • Override metalness value in the ign-gazebo level. This is not desirable as we integrate new mesh formats with PBR support in the future, e.g. glTF2. The metalness value specified in the mesh would be overriden.

Update:

Ended up changing default metalness value in common::Pbr class.

values.description:
This PR is an ABI compatible version of [229](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/229), it uses a “[hack](https://community.kde.org/Policies/Binary_Compatibility_Issues_With_C%2B%2B#Adding_new_data_members_to_classes_without_d-pointer)” including a static hash map to emulate a private data pointer for the animation class that doesn’t have one \(it will be PIMPL-ized in the next major release, breaking ABI\).

Note, there is some issues with const correctness that forced me to the ugly “const\_cast”, I didn’t consider it a critical aspect since it will be removed in the next version anyway but might be nice to fix.

It is to be tested through gazebo following the instructions in [the upstream PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/536/using-interpolate_x-sdf-value-for/diff).
values.title: Add interpolateX member to the Animation class

Note, there is some issues with const correctness that forced me to the ugly “const\_cast”, I didn’t consider it a critical aspect since it will be removed in the next version anyway but might be nice to fix.

It is to be tested through gazebo following the instructions in [the upstream PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/536/using-interpolate_x-sdf-value-for/diff).
summary.html:
This PR is an ABI compatible version of 229, it uses a “hack” including a static hash map to emulate a private data pointer for the animation class that doesn’t have one (it will be PIMPL-ized in the next major release, breaking ABI).

Note, there is some issues with const correctness that forced me to the ugly “const_cast”, I didn’t consider it a critical aspect since it will be removed in the next version anyway but might be nice to fix.

It is to be tested through gazebo following the instructions in the upstream PR.
